pyplotgen.src package¶

Submodules¶

pyplotgen.src.AnimationPanel module¶

pyplotgen.src.CaseGallerySetup module¶

author

Nicolas Strike

date

2019

class src.CaseGallerySetup.CaseGallerySetup(case_definition, clubb_folders=[], diff_datasets=None, sam_folders=[''], wrf_folders=[''], plot_les=False, plot_budgets=False, plot_r408=False, plot_hoc=False, e3sm_dirs=[], cam_folders=[], time_height=False, animation=None)¶

Bases: object

A case is basically a collection of variable groups and panels that share attributes like start/end time and get plotted together. This is a generic class used by Case_Definitions.py to provide functionality. In order to create a new case, please add the case’s definition to Case_Definitions.py (don’t forget to add the definition to the list ALL_CASES = […] at the bottom of the Case_Definitions.py file).

getDiffLinesBetweenPanels(panelA, panelB, get_y_diff=False)¶

Given two panels of type Panel, this function calculates the numerical difference between each line of the two panels and returns the numerical values as a list [] for each line in the panel.

This function assumes that the dependent_data lines are in the same order on each panel and that each panel has the same number of lines

Parameters

  • panelA – The first panel for comparison

  • panelB – The second panel for comparison

  • get_y_diff – Default behavior is to return the difference along the x-axis, setting this to True returns the difference on the y-axis

Returns

A 2D list containing the numerical values for the difference between each line in the given panels.

plot(output_folder, replace_images=False, no_legends=False, thin_lines=False, show_alphabetic_id=False)¶

Plot all panels associated with the case, these will be saved to image files in the <<output>>/<<casename>> folder

Parameters

  • output_folder – Absolute name of the folder to save output into.

  • replace_images – If True, pyplotgen will overwrite images with the same name. If False (default), pyplotgen will add a timestamp to the end of every filename (even if there’s no filename conflict)

  • no_legends – If True, pyplotgen will not include a legend on output graphs. If False (default), legends will be displayed.

  • thin_lines – If True, lines plotted will be much thinner than usual. If False (default), lines are plotted according to the thickness defined in config/Style_definitions.py

  • show_alphabetic_id – If True, pyplotgen will add an alphabetic label to the top right corner of each plot. These labels will rotate through a-z incrementally. If there are more than 26 plots, it will rotate 2 dimensionally, e.g. (aa), (ab), (ac),…,(ba),(bb),(bc) and etc. If show_alphabetic_id is False (default), this label is not displayed. The behavior for rotations greater than zz is not defined, and although pyplotgen won’t crash it may start to use weird characters. The rotation resets between each case, e.g. if one case ends on label (ad), the next case will start on (a).

Returns

None

pyplotgen.src.Contour module¶

author

Steffen Domke

date

June 2020

class src.Contour.Contour(x_data, y_data, c_data, colors='', label='Unlabeled plot')¶

Bases: object

This class holds any information necessary to create a contour plot using pyplot, including the numerical values, format style, and a label for the plot. In the future we would like to seperate the dependent_data from the format.

pyplotgen.src.ContourPanel module¶

Child class derived from Panel. Takes the same variable definitions as a Panel for profile plots. But needs the unaveraged netcdf data. The changed plot routine outputs contour plots instead of profile plots.

author

Steffen Domke

date

July 2020

class src.ContourPanel.ContourPanel(plots, panel_type='timeheight', title='Unnamed panel', dependent_title='dependent variable')¶

Bases: src.Panel.Panel

ContourPanel class derived from Panel The difference is that the plot routine will generate a timeheight plot instead of a standard profile plot.

plot(output_folder, casename, replace_images=False, no_legends=True, thin_lines=False, alphabetic_id='', paired_plots=True)¶

Generate a single contourf plot from the given data

Parameters

  • output_folder – String containing path to folder in which the image files should be created

  • casename – The name of the case that is plotted in this panel

  • replace_images – Switch to tell pyplotgen if existing files should be overwritten

  • alphabetic_id – A string printed into the Panel at coordinates (.9,.9) as an identifier.

Returns

None

pyplotgen.src.DataReader module¶

author

Nicolas Strike

date

Early 2019

class src.DataReader.DataReader¶

Bases: object

This class is responsible for handling nc files. Given nc files it reads them and returns NetCDF Dataset objects to python. It is also responsible for performing the time-averaging calculation at load time.

Author

Nicolas Strike

Date

January 2019

cleanup()¶

This is the cleanup method. This is called on the instance’s destruction to deallocate resources that may be held (e.g. dataset files).

Returns

None

Author

Nicolas Strike

getAxisTitle(ncdf_datasets, varname)¶

Find netcdf variable in ncdf_datasets matching varname and generate the axis title from its attributes

Parameters

  • ncdf_datasets – List of datasets

  • varname – Variable name

Returns

String containing units and variable name to be used as axis title

getLongName(ncdf_datasets, varnames)¶

Find netcdf variable in ncdf_datasets matching any name in varnames and get its long_name attribute

Parameters

  • ncdf_datasets – List of datasets

  • varnames – List of variable names

Returns

String containing the long name of the variable that was found, often used as a title

getNcdfSourceModel(ncdf_dataset)¶

Guesses the model that outputted a given ncdf file. Currently does this by investigating which type of elevation is outputted (e.g. altitude, z, lev). If there is not elevation parameter found, and the filename contains ‘sfc’ it will return a generic ‘sfc calculations’ value.

Parameters

ncdf_dataset – A netCDF4 Dataset object containing data from some supported model (e.g. CLUBB, SAM)

Returns

The (estimated) name of the model that outputted the nc file

getVarData(netcdf_dataset, ncdf_variable)¶

Given a Dataset and NetCdfVariable object, this function returns the numerical dependent_data and independent_data for the given variable.

TODO: Split up reading and averaging into different functions

since time-height plots do not need averaging

Parameters

  • netcdf_dataset – Dataset containing the given variable

  • ncdf_variable – NetCdfVariable object to get dependent_data values for

Returns

The list of numeric values for the given variable

loadFolder(folder_path, ignore_git=True)¶

Finds all dataset files in a given folder and loads them using the appropriate helper class.

Parameters

  • folder_path – A list of paths to folders containing nc files

  • ignore_git – Ignore files and paths that contain ‘.git’ in their name

Returns

A 2 dimensional dictionary where a case_key (e.g. gabls3_rad) contains a dictionary defining filenames behind a filetype key (e.g. zm) For example: to access the zm dependent_data for gabls3_rad, simply call clubb_datasets[‘gabls3’][‘zm’]

Author

Nicolas Strike

class src.DataReader.NetCdfVariable(names, ncdf_data, independent_var_names=None, conversion_factor=1, start_time=0, end_time=- 1, min_height=0, max_height=- 1, avg_axis=0, model_name='unknown')¶

Bases: object

Class used for conveniently storing the information about a given netcdf variable

filterDatasets()¶

Looks through the nc files for a case and finds the Dataset containing the requested variable and assigns it to self.ncdf_data. Assumes self.ncdf_data is a dictionary.

Returns

None

trimArray(start_value, end_value, data=None, axis=0)¶

Remove all dependent_data elements from the variable that are not between the start and end value. Assumes the dependent_data is sorted. If the optional data parameter is used, it will restrict to the indices of where the start/end values are in that dataset rather than the variables dependent_data itself.

TODO: Test with multiple dimensions!

Parameters

  • start_value – The smallest possible value

  • end_value – The largest possible value

  • data – A list of dependent_data values to find start/ending indices for constraining rather than using the NetCdfVariable’s dependent_data. Must be specified if called on a multidimensional variable.

  • axis – The index for the axis to be trimmed (0=time, 1=height). Only needed for multidimensional data.

Returns

None, operates in place

pyplotgen.src.Line module¶

author

Nicolas Strike

date

Early 2019

class src.Line.Line(x_data, y_data, line_format='', label='Unlabeled plot')¶

Bases: object

This class holds information commonly passed around when using plot dependent_data. Data included is anything necessary to graph a line using pyplot, including the numerical values, line format style, and a label for the plot. In the future we would like to seperate the dependent_data from the format.

pyplotgen.src.Panel module¶

author

Nicolas Strike

date

Mid 2019

class src.Panel.Panel(plots, panel_type='profile', title='Unnamed panel', dependent_title='dependent variable', sci_scale=None, centered=False)¶

Bases: object

Represents an individual panel/graph. Each panel contains a number of details specific to it, such as a title, axis labels, and lines. Each panel can be plotted/saved to a file.

EXTENSION = '.png'¶
TYPE_ANIMATION = 'animation'¶
TYPE_BUDGET = 'budget'¶
TYPE_PROFILE = 'profile'¶
TYPE_TIMEHEIGHT = 'timeheight'¶
TYPE_TIMESERIES = 'timeseries'¶
plot(output_folder, casename, replace_images=False, no_legends=True, thin_lines=False, alphabetic_id='', paired_plots=True)¶

Saves a single panel/graph as image to the output directory specified by the pyplotgen launch parameters

Parameters

  • output_folder – String containing path to folder in which the image files should be created

  • casename – The name of the case that is plotted in this panel

  • replace_images – Switch to tell pyplotgen if existing files should be overwritten

  • no_legends – If False, a legend will be generated for this Panel

  • thin_lines – If True, the line_width for this Panel is specified in Style_definitions.THIN_LINE_THICKNESS

  • alphabetic_id – A string printed into the Panel at coordinates (.9,.9) as an identifier.

Paired_plots

If no format is specified and paired_plots is True, use the color/style rotation specified in Style_definitions.py

Returns

None

pyplotgen.src.VariableGroup module¶

author

Nicolas Strike

date

Mid 2019

class src.VariableGroup.VariableGroup(case, clubb_datasets=None, les_dataset=None, coamps_dataset=None, r408_dataset=None, hoc_dataset=None, cam_datasets=None, e3sm_datasets=None, sam_datasets=None, wrf_datasets=None)¶

Bases: object

This is the parent VariableGroup class. All other panel groups should be created as a subclass of this one. Properties and methods common to each PanelGroup can be found here.

A VariableGroup child defines Lines, Panels, etc., and is responsible for calculating any ‘calculated’ variables from netcdf

addVariable(variable_def_dict)¶

Given basic details about a variable, this creates lines/panels for the variable and then adds that variable to the list of all variables for this VariableGroup

Parameters

variable_def_dict – A dict containing the information defining a variable. These definitions are declared inside a VariableGroup child class, e.g. VariableGroupBase.

Valid dict keys/options include:

var_names: A list of names various models refer to this variable as. E.g. [‘wprtp’, ‘WPRTP’, ‘wpqtp’]. This

parameter can also take in references to calc functions. Names/functions are prioritized left -> right.

[model name]_conv_factor: (optional) Numeric value to scale a model’s variable by. E.g. 1/1000, or 100

Valid models are: clubb, hoc, r408, sam, cam, wrf, e3sm. E.g. “clubb_conv_factor”

type: (optional) Override the default type ‘profile’ with either ‘budget’ or ‘timeseries’ title: (optional) Override the default panel title, or provide one if it’s not specified in the netcdf file. sci_scale: (optional) A numerical power of ten to scale the panel axis to. E.g. a value of “4” results in the

axis being scaled to x 1e4

axis_title: (optional) Override the default dependent axis title, or provide one if it’s not

specified in the netcdf file.

lines: * Defines lines to plot for budget cases. Passed seperately because

it’s a lot of text. The lines parameter currently does not support defining model-specific names/functions This is given in the form of a list of lines, here’s an example:

1
thlm_budget_lines = [

{‘var_names’: [‘thlm_bt’], ‘legend_label’: ‘thlm_bt’}, {‘var_names’: [‘thlm_ma’], ‘legend_label’: ‘thlm_ma’}, {‘var_names’: [‘thlm_ta’], ‘legend_label’: ‘thlm_ta’}, {‘var_names’: [‘thlm_mc’], ‘legend_label’: ‘thlm_mc’}, {‘var_names’: [‘thlm_clipping’,self.getThlmClipping], ‘legend_label’: ‘thlm_clipping’}, {‘var_names’: [‘radht’], ‘legend_label’: ‘radht’}, {‘var_names’: [‘ls_forcing’, self.getThlmLsforcing], ‘legend_label’: ‘thlm_ls_forcing’}, {‘var_names’: [‘thlm_residual’,self.getThlmResidual], ‘legend_label’: ‘thlm_residual’},

]

Returns

None

generatePanels()¶

Generates a set of panels from the plots stored in self. Does not return anything, simply assigns the panels into self.panels

Returns

None

getTextDefiningDataset()¶

Finds a dataset from which text names and descriptions can be pulled from. By default, it is always clubb, however if pyplotgen is not plotting clubb then it will return the first dataset it can find.

Returns

A list of all Dataset objects for all models

getVarForCalculations(varname, datasets, conversion_factor=1)¶

This function is used within model_calc functions to get the dependent_data of a certain variable, constrained between a min/max height.

Parameters

  • varname – The name of the variable as a string.

  • datasets – A netCDF4 Dataset object or dict of such containing the model output being plotted.

  • conversion_factor – This is a numerical value that will be multiplied element-wise to the variable. It’s useful for doing basic model to model conversions, e.g. SAM -> CLUBB.

Returns

A tuple containing the dependent_data for the variable, the height data, and the datasets

isSurfaceData(dataset)¶

Returns False if the given dataset contains a height var, True otherwise

Parameters

dataset – A netCDF4 Dataset object

Returns

False if a dataset contains a height var, True otherwise

pickNonZeroOutput(output1, output2)¶

Sometimes there are more than 1 ways to calculate a variable, and it is impossible to know which equation to use before hand. In these cases, all equations should be used and their output given to this function. This function will then attempt to determine which of the outputs from the equations is most likely to be the expected answer.

This function currently works by determining picking the non-nan and non-zero array. In the event that both arrays contain non-nan and non-zero output, it will return output1.

If both arrays are zero or nan, then it will return the first array arbitrarily.

Example usage: def get_rc_coef_zm_X_wprcp_coamps_calc(self, dataset_override=None):

wprlp, z, dataset = self.getVarForCalculations([‘thlpqcp’, ‘wpqcp’, ‘wprlp’], dataset) ex0, z, dataset = self.getVarForCalculations([‘ex0’], dataset) p, z, dataset = self.getVarForCalculations(‘p’, dataset) thvm, z, dataset = self.getVarForCalculations(‘thvm’, dataset) output1 = wprlp * (2.5e6 / (1004.67 * ex0) - 1.61 * thvm) output2 = wprlp * (2.5e6 / (1004.67 * ((p / 1.0e5) ** (287.04 / 1004.67))) - 1.61 * thvm) output = self.pickMostLikelyOutputList(output1, output2) return output, z

Parameters

  • output1 – An arraylike list of numbers outputted from a variable calculation (e.g. output1 = wprlp * (2.5e6 / (1004.67 * ex0) - 1.61 * thvm)

  • output2 – An arraylike list of numbers outputted from a variable calculation (e.g. output2 = wprlp * (2.5e6 / (1004.67 * ((p / 1.0e5) ** (287.04 / 1004.67))) - 1.61 * thvm)

Returns

The listlike array of the two datasets most likely to be the correct answer.

pyplotgen.src.interoperability module¶

Author

Steffen Domke

Date

March 2020

This file contains functions used to guarantee operability on different operating systems.

src.interoperability.clean_path(input_string)¶

Removes characters from a path string that are not valid for the operating system

Parameters

input_string – Path string to have characters removed

Returns

A cleaned version of the path

src.interoperability.clean_title(string)¶

Cleans plot titles so they can be used as part of a file name. Matplotlib plot titles may contain latex code enclosed in ‘$’ characters. This code should be removed entirely to avoid having invalid characters in file names.

Parameters

string – Title of a plot which is used to generate a file name

Returns

A cleaned version of the input string
